start.headline: Your job title says nothing about your work. Let's look at what you actually do.
start.subheadline: AI doesn't automate jobs—it automates tasks. Some of what you do is already being done by AI. Some of it can't be. The difference isn't your title. It's the specific activities that fill your days.
start.body: This takes 10 minutes. You'll describe 3–5 of your core tasks. We'll analyze them for patterns that matter—not to scare you, but to show you where your leverage is.
start.requirements: Describe 3-5 core tasks from your actual work

taskLevel.description: Based on what you actually do, not job titles

signalExtraction.title: Signal Extraction
signalExtraction.description: We read patterns in your work, not industry statistics

agencyAffirming.title: Agency-Affirming
agencyAffirming.description: Shows you where your leverage is, not what to fear

manualInput.headline: Walk me through a typical week. What actually takes your time?
manualInput.killerSentence: The details reveal the truth. Be specific.

instructions.line1: Think about how you spend your time each week.
instructions.line2: Focus on activities, not titles or responsibilities.

example.good: "I run weekly standups, chase engineers for updates, and decide when to escalate blockers"

example1.rich: I run weekly standups, chase engineers for updates, and decide when to escalate blockers

example2.rich: I pull sales data, build pivot tables, and write narrative summaries for non-technical stakeholders

manualInput.placeholder: Describe a specific task or activity... (e.g., "I spend 3 hours weekly chasing updates from engineers who don't respond to Slack")

questions.headline: A few clarifying questions
questions.subheadline: Similar-sounding tasks can have very different exposure profiles. These questions help us distinguish between them.
questions.killerSentence: These questions have no wrong answers—only honest ones.

contextDependency.prompt: Think about your last 5 working days. How many of your completed tasks could a competent new hire do on day one—with access to your files, but no handover from you?

accountabilityScope.prompt: When something goes wrong in your area, who explains why to leadership—you, or someone else?

environmentalPressure.prompt: In the past 12 months, have you noticed any of these at work?

options.toolReplacement: A tool now does something I used to do manually
options.reviewAiOutput: I've been asked to 'review AI output' instead of creating from scratch
options.justifyHuman: I've had to justify why a task needs a human instead of automation

analysis.headline: Analyzing your work profile
analysis.subheadline: We're reading your work, not looking up your job.
analysis.killerSentence: We're not looking up your job. We're reading your work.

processingSteps.step1: Mapping your tasks to AI capability domains...
processingSteps.step2: Analyzing decision patterns and judgment requirements...

justification.headline: Analysis complete
justification.subheadline: Before showing your score, here is the reasoning behind your assessment.

capabilities.title: Where AI systems perform well
capabilities.description: These capabilities overlap with parts of your described work:

limitations.title: Where AI systems struggle
limitations.description: These aspects of your work remain difficult to automate:

explanation.low: Limited input makes this assessment less precise. Consider adding more task details for a refined analysis.
explanation.moderate: Sufficient detail for a reasonable assessment. Additional specificity would improve precision.
explanation.high: Strong input quality. This assessment reflects a detailed understanding of your work.

content.line1: Signal strength reflects how much information we have to work with.
content.line2: It considers: number of tasks provided, specificity of descriptions, and consistency of clarifying answers.
content.line3: A low signal does not mean high or low exposure. It means the assessment has wider confidence intervals.
content.line4: You can improve signal strength by providing more tasks or more detailed descriptions.

score.headline: Your AI exposure score
score.headlineTemplate: Your current work has {{score}}% task exposure to AI
score.killerSentence: This isn't a verdict. It's a lens.

protected.label: Protected
protected.meaning: Your work has strong human moats. Most of what you do requires judgment, relationships, or accountability that AI cannot replicate.
protected.action: Your work is well-positioned. See the breakdown to understand why.

mixed.label: Mixed
mixed.meaning: Your work is a mix of automatable and human-exclusive tasks. Your opportunity: move time from the first to the second.
mixed.action: There are specific changes you can make to shift the balance.

exposed.label: Exposed
exposed.meaning: A significant portion of your work follows patterns AI handles well. This isn't a crisis—it's a signal.
exposed.action: The roadmap will show you how to reposition.

critical.label: Critical
critical.meaning: Most of your described work falls where AI is already capable. This requires active attention—not panic.
critical.action: The good news: targeted changes can significantly reduce this exposure.

reductionTeaser.label: Reduction potential
reductionTeaser.template: With {{changes}} targeted changes, your exposure could shift
reductionTeaser.locked: See which changes in full report

score.disclaimer: This is a task exposure assessment, not a job loss prediction. Exposure indicates overlap with AI capabilities, not replacement timeline.

breakdown.headline: Your work isn't one thing. It's many things.
breakdown.subheadline: Each task is assigned to a future-role category—not just risk levels, but how the task will exist in 2-5 years.
breakdown.killerSentence: Your work isn't one thing. It's many things—some stable, some shifting.
breakdown.chartCaption: Higher values indicate greater overlap with AI capabilities. Lower is better.

exposureDescriptors.high: AI already does this reliably. Delegate to AI now.
exposureDescriptors.medium: AI does heavy lifting, you provide oversight. Learn to orchestrate.
exposureDescriptors.low: Requires trust, accountability, or ambiguity AI cannot handle. Expand this.

automated.label: AUTOMATED
automated.meaning: AI already does this reliably. Task likely disappears within 1-3 years.
automated.action: Delegate to AI now. Reclaim time for higher-value work.

aiAssisted.label: AI-ASSISTED
aiAssisted.meaning: AI does heavy lifting, human oversight needed. Role shifts from creator to editor.
aiAssisted.action: Learn to orchestrate AI. Move value from execution to judgment.

humanMoat.label: HUMAN MOAT
humanMoat.meaning: Requires trust, accountability, or ambiguity AI cannot handle. Protected 5+ years.
humanMoat.action: Expand and deepen. Make this larger share of your work.

roadmap.headline: Your exposure isn't fixed. Here's how it shifts.
roadmap.subheadline: These recommendations are specific to your task profile. Each one shifts work toward areas where human judgment remains essential.
roadmap.killerSentence: The goal isn't to outrun AI. It's to work where AI can't follow.

progressHints.empty: Check off actions you commit to taking
progressHints.complete: All actions committed. Ready to transform your work.

delegateToAi.title: Delegate to AI
delegateToAi.description: Tasks in "Automated" category you still do manually. Stop doing them, or use AI tooling to compress them.

elevateRole.title: Elevate Your Role
elevateRole.description: Tasks in "AI-Assisted" where you can move from executor to orchestrator.

amplifyMoat.title: Amplify Your Moat
amplifyMoat.description: Tasks in "Human Moat" you should deliberately expand or deepen.

summary.headline: Assessment complete
summary.killerSentence: Knowing isn't enough. What will you do differently?
summary.nextSteps: Review the recommended actions and consider how they apply to your current role.
summary.returnPrompt: Assessments like this are most useful when revisited every 3-6 months. Your work changes. So should your strategy.

scenario.headline: Two paths forward
scenario.subheadline: The change is coming either way. The only question is whether you're steering it.
scenario.killerSentence: The change is coming either way. The only question is whether you're steering it.

timeframes.months6: Current work continues, but perceived value declines as others adopt AI tools.
timeframes.months12: Tasks you do manually become expectations AI handles. More work, less differentiation.
timeframes.months24: When restructuring happens, your role looks like overhead. Competing with those who adapted.

timeframes.months6: You adopt AI tools for automatable tasks, freeing time for higher-judgment work.
timeframes.months12: Known for judgment and orchestration, not execution. Exposure score decreases.
timeframes.months24: When restructuring happens, positioned in work AI cannot replace. The shift accelerated you.

scenario.supportingCopy: Most professionals adapt eventually. The ones who adapt first don't just survive—they gain leverage. The window isn't closing, but it is narrowing.

aiOrchestrator.name: AI Orchestrator

aiOrchestrator.description: You coordinate complex workflows and manage AI outputs. Your value lies in knowing when to trust automation and when to intervene.

judgmentSpecialist.description: You handle situations where the right answer is unclear. Your experience and instincts guide decisions that algorithms cannot make.

hybridProfessional.name: Hybrid Professional

hybridProfessional.description: Your work spans multiple domains. Some tasks will shift to AI, others will remain yours. Flexibility is your advantage.

transitionCandidate.description: Much of your current work follows predictable patterns. The roadmap below focuses on repositioning toward higher-judgment activities.
